descriptions.description: Son of King Archidamos II and Eupolia
Half-brother of King Agis II and Teleutias
Agesilaos was born in 444/3 and about 402 married Kleora (cf. Aristomenidas) who bore him three children, Archidamos, Eupolia, and Prolyta.<sup>mC</sup>

When, after the death of Agis II in the summer of 399, Agis’ son Leotychidas was disqualified, Agesilaos—particularly through the influence of his boyhood friend Lysander—received the throne.<sup>Cujg</sup>
Likewise, through the efforts of Lysander was Agesilaos appointed the commander in the war against Persia. He sailed in the spring of 396 from Aulis to Ephesus.<sup>kCh</sup>
He conducted the war in Asia Minor until the summer of 394, when he was recalled because of political developments in Greece.<sup>Cxwlva</sup>

In thirty days he marched to Boeotia, where he established a camp at Chaeroneia on the 25th or 26th of August 394 and soon thereafter defeated the enemies of Sparta in the battle of Coronea.<sup>Cm</sup>
To heal the wound that he had received in the battle he took himself to Delphi and from there travelled home on a ship.<sup>Cx</sup>
In 391 he laid waste to Argos and continued on to Corinth where he had the long walls of Lechaeum torn down.<sup>Cy</sup>
In the summer of the next year <390> he was active at the Isthmus<sup>Cop</sup>. There he fought on behalf of the Achaeans against the Acarnanians.<sup>Cp</sup>
At the peace conference in Sparta in 387/6 he forced through the recognition of the King’s Peace on the part of the Thebans and the dissolution of the just founded city Corinth-Argos.<sup>Cz</sup>
In the fall of 381 he struck against Phlius, which he took after a siege of twenty months.<sup>C</sup>

In similar fashion he participated in the great struggle between Thebes and Sparta. He undertook two operations to Boeotia in 378/7. A wound, which he received on the march back, kept him from the theater of war for a long time,<sup>Cb</sup> so he acted all the more energetically against Thebes in 371 at the congress at Sparta, when he excluded the Thebans from the common peace.<sup>Cq</sup>

After the catastrophe at Leuctra he campaigned with the full army against Mantinea, but had to withdraw to Sparta at the approach of the Thebans.<sup>C</sup> By his careful handling he saved the country from the invasion of Epaminondas in the winter of 370/69.<sup>r</sup>
Around 364 he travelled to Asia to earn money for Sparta and fought there together with the Athenian Timotheos for the interests of Ariobarzanes.<sup>Af</sup>
In 362 we find the king back in Greece, where shortly before the battle of Mantinea he saved Sparta a second time from a Theban invasion.<sup>Csc</sup>

In 361 he went to Egypt to enter the service of Tachos, to earn money for Sparta as the leader of a mercenary band. When he was demoted by Tachos he went over to Nectanebo and did important service for him. Therefore, when he prepared his return home, he was loaded with rich gifts. He never reached his homeland, but died in the winter of 360/59 between Egypt and Cyrene in the “harbor of Menelaos.” His body was brought back to Sparta.<sup>tde</sup>

In 388/7 he led a successful campaign against the Argives<sup>e</sup>. In 385/4 he forced Mantinea to disband the league it had formed<sup>f</sup>. In the year 381 he invaded Chalcidice with a great army, but died shortly after the capture of Torone in Summer 380.
His body was brought to Sparta<sup>bg</sup>.
After the death of his father in 371 Agesipolis succeeded to the throne,
but he died after about a one-year reign and left no children<sup>abc</sup>.

The trip of Agetoridas then, if it is at all historical, must fall in the period 399-388.

Father of Echestratos and, according to one version, of the lawgiver Lycurgus<sup>ab</sup>.
He was the eponymous king of the house of the Agids—obviously a mythical person<sup>ab</sup>.
During his reign (1061-1030/29) the helots were subjugated<sup>c</sup>. He is also made the ultimate ancestor of the mythical Amphikles<sup>d</sup>.
King from the house of the Eurypontids

After the death of Archidamos Agis assumed the throne in 427/6<sup>k</sup>. In the years 426 and 425 he twice led the army into Attica.<sup>ab</sup> With his fellow king Pleistoanax in 421 he underwrote the peace of Nicias and the alliance with Athens.<sup>c</sup>

In 419 he marched with the assembled army to Leuctra, but turned back to Sparta without accomplishing anything.<sup>d</sup> In the next summer he campaigned twice against the Argives and besieged them because of their alliance with Mantinea<sup>em</sup>. In a third campaign at the beginning of the winter of 417 he caused the newly built walls of Argos to be torn down<sup>f</sup>.

In spring 413 Agis invaded Attica and seized Decelea, where he remained as commander<sup>g</sup>. From here he undertook in the following winter a campaign against the Oitaians and the Achaeans living in Phthiotis, to reestablish the influence of the Spartans on the Malean Gulf<sup>h</sup>. From Decelea Agis supported all rebellions against Athens in Asia Minor and along the Hellespont and tried several times to take the city<sup>io</sup>. He did not take part in the siege of Athens in 405/4<sup>nq</sup>, although he did offer his good ofices to the Athenians<sup>p</sup>.

After the fall of Athens he led a long campaign against Elis<sup>t</sup> and visited Delphi. On his return trip he fell sick and died soon after his arrival in Sparta, probably in the summer of 399<sup>lrs</sup>.

He succeeded his father in 338 and ruled for nine years<sup>d</sup>. In 333, as leader of the opposition to Alexander the Great, Agis travelled to Siphnos to meet Pharnabazos and Autophradates, the commanders of the Persian fleet; he obtained money and troops from them. Then he travelled to Halicarnassos where he led some of the survivors of the Greek mer­cenaries from the battle of Issos to Crete<sup>ce</sup>. After he returned to Sparta he besieged Megalopolis, but in a battle fought there against Antipater, he was killed (in 331 or 330)<sup>fg</sup>.
He and his brothers (Eupylidas, Chairis, Lykos, Alexon, Eraton, and Gylippos) fell at Messene sometime after 369.

descriptions.description: Son of Eudamidas (2) II and Agesistrata
He was the first king of Sparta to attempt to recover her military strength through an increase in the number of citizen-soldiers by cancellation of debt, distribution of land, and enfranchisement.
He was opposed by the wealthy and by Leonidas (1) II, the Agiad king, though a large minority of the fully enfranchised citizen body supported Agis.
With the help of his advisers and supporters, Lysandros (1), Mandrokleidas, and Agesilaos (2), he expelled Leonidas, brought Kleombrotos (1) II to the throne, and passed a bill cancelling debt.

He led an army to aid the Achaean League against the Aetolians, but no engagement was fought. In his absence his opponents gained the upper hand. (Pausanias confuses the actions of the Aetolians and the Spartans under Agis in his reading of Plutarch’s life of Aratus.)
Leonidas II returned from exile and forced Agis to seek sanctuary. Agis was betrayed, tried by the ephors, and executed.

Remarks: Bradford distinguishes [1. 2f] [= p. 26 (2) from the Alcandridas of [2a-e] [= p. 27 (6)] regarding the latter as th grandfather of the former, whom he identifies with P. Aelius Alcandridas (III), son of Damocratidas, the prominent Spartan athlete and magistrate of the 1<sup>st</sup> half of the 3<sup>rd</sup> c. AD. This is rejected by A. J. S. Spawforth ABSA 80, 1985, 246, 247 n. 147, because he dates [1] in the 3rd quarter of the 2<sup>nd</sup> c. AD. He considers [1. 2a-e] as P. Aelius Alcandridas (II), the grandfather of P. Aelius Alcandridas (III). Settipani, 496 places his lifetime from AD 130 to after AD 155/65.

descriptions.description: Gerousias [for the second or more time] in the year of Nike[phoros h]o [Markou].

“Remarks: The date of the first is based on prosopographical considerations (Woodward loc. cit and A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 210-11 n. 69). Which leads A. M. Woodward to restore the lost name of the eponymous official by analogy with IG V 1. 63 ll. 16-17, a catalogue of ephors in the term of C. Julius Eudamos, A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 27 convincingly restores [Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος)] Ἀλκ[ανδ]ρίδας β[ουαγός] in [1. 1.16]. If this restoration is correct, prosopographically he is the earliest known and otherwise unattested member of this family with Roman citizenship, hence P. Aelius Alcandridas (1). Considering the chronological evidence of this inscription, it is most likely that he had become a Roman citizen through a personal grant of Hadrian on the occasion of one of the emperor’s two visits at Sparta (in AD 124/5 and 128/9). Cf. W. Weber, Untersuchungen zur Geschichte des Kaisers Hadrianus (Leipzig 1907)188-89 n. 671. 211 ns. 744-45; H. Box JRS 21 1931, 201; Chrimes Ancient Sparta 465; Halfmann Itinera principum, 137, 192; Cartledge and Spawforth 108. This would mean that Alcandridas was already of advanced age when ensitos.

“An unpublished inscription discussed in Steinhauer Eurykles testifies that C. Julius Eurykles Herculanus (LAC 462, ARC 105) died in the patronomate of (C. Julius) Nicephoros son of Marcus attested in [2], which should be dated to ca. AD 136/7, see G. Steinhauer, ABSA 93, 1998, 431 n 9. This date allows the identification of P. Aelius Alcandridas in [2] with the homonymous person in [1].

“For the nature of the post and title of bouagos [1(?), 2] in the Spartan agoge of the Roman imperial period see Cartledge and Spawforth, esp 203-204; Kennell, Institutions, 181-85 and id., Gymnasium esp 41-42, 108-09. Perhaps f. P. Aelius Nikandridas (LAC 16) see stemma in Spawforth, op. cit., 246 tab 6 (Aelii Alcandridae); see infra, Appendix, Stemma II.”

descriptions.description: The poet of Laconian choral lyric from the second half of the seventh century. Over his antecedents there is no agreement. (1) Alcman came from Sardis<sup>a</sup>. Added to that is the reference that Alcman was the slave of the Lacedaemonian Agesidas<sup>b</sup>. (2) Elsewhere<sup>c</sup> the poet is described as Λάκων ἀπὸ Μεσσόας and is given Damas or Titaros as his father. (3) Ale­xan­der the Aetolian<sup>d</sup> takes a middle position in an epigram; he holds Alcman for a Laconian, but says that his ancestors came from Sardis. In a mosaic portrait bust Alcman was associated with Sappho and Anacreon<sup>e</sup>.

descriptions.description: Father of Akrotatos (2), king of Sparta

He succeeded to the throne despite the fact that Kleonymos (1), son of Kleomenes II, was alive. Kleonymos, however, was given command of the armies. Their rivalry, intensified, no doubt, by Akrotatos’ adultery with the wife of Kleonymos, led to Kleonymos’ leaving Sparta and joining Pyrrhus.<sup>bd</sup>
Areus was an active king, forming connections in Sicily<sup>g</sup>, Crete<sup>ei</sup>, Egypt<sup>jk</sup>, and possibly Judaea<sup>h</sup>.

He attempted to restore the Spartan hegemony of the Peloponnesus and opposed the Macedonian forces in Greece, although he was forced into a brief alliance with them to forestall the invasion of Pyrrhus into Laconia<sup>f</sup>.
He was killed in an attempt to force the Macedonian lines at Corinth, 265 BC<sup>c</sup>

In SIG<sup>3</sup> 430 the Delphians grant proxenia to “King Areus, son of King Akrotatos and Queen Chilonis.” The editor believes that this refers to Areus I, since it seemed unlikely to him that the Delphians would grant proxenia to a child, albeit a king. Akrotatos, however, the father of Areus I, was not a king. There is but one king Akrotatos and he is the father of Areus II. Moreover, the Chilonis of the inscription might well be the widow of Kleonymus and lover of Akrotatos the king [26.17-18].)
He was born after the death of his father at Megalopolis, 262 BC. Leonidas (1), the son of Kleonymos (1), was regent. He was an Agiad king.
He died of disease when he was eight years old.
He was exiled from Sparta by Nabis and restored against the wishes of the government of Sparta by the Achaean league.
In 184 BC he was an envoy to the Romans and he denounced the Achaean league.

Grandmother of Agis (1) IV, Archidamos (3) <V>, and Hippomedon (1)<sup>a</sup> <Polybius (IV 35.13) states that Hippomedon was in the line of Eurypontid succession, which would be readily understandable if he were the grandson of a king. Agesilaos, his father, was the son of a Eudamidas. Eudamidas I was a Eurypontid. It seems likely then that Archidamia was the wife of Eudamidas I.>

During the invasion of Laconia by Pyrrhus, 272 BC, Archidamia opposed a plan to send the women and children of Sparta to Crete. She organized the women to fortify the city, carry weapons, and treat the wounded. She aided and encouraged the Spartan soldiers.<sup>c</sup>
She was one of the wealthiest women in Sparta, but she supported the reforms of Agis IV with both her money and her influence.<sup>a</sup>
She was executed after his fall in 241 BC<sup>b</sup>

According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house, son of Theopompos and father of Zeuxidamos. He is supposed to have died before his father. Perhaps to be identified with Archidamos (Poralla 154).
According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house and son of Anaxidamos and father of Agasikles
King from the house of the Eurypontids
Father of Agis II (from his first marriage with his step-aunt Lampido)<sup>ab</sup> and Agesilaos II and Kyniska (by his second wife Eupolia)<sup>acfg</sup>

When shortly before 476 Leotychidas had to go into exile at Tegea, his grandson Archidamos assumed the rule<sup>e</sup>. Whether he had already taken part in the battles of Tegea in 473 and Dipaia can not be known. He was first mentioned in the great earthquake in Sparta in 464, where he saved the state through his presence of mind<sup>h</sup>. He distinguished himself in the ensuing battles against the Messenians<sup>d</sup>.
Archidamos commanded the first invasion of Attica in the year 431 and 430<sup>klm</sup>. In 429 he took Plataea and in the next year led an army into Attica for the third time.<sup>no</sup>
He became sick and died at the latest in the Winter 427/6.

descriptions.description: King from the house of the Eurypontids (born about 400)
Son of Agesilaos II and Kleora.
Father of Agis III, Eudamidas I and Agesilaos<sup>gmo</sup>
In 371 he led the defeated army of Kleombrotos back from Megara to Sparta. (Diodorus XV 54-55 in error puts Archidamos also at the battle of Leuctra.)<sup>bc</sup>
In the years 367 and 364 Archidamos campaigned against the Arcadians in the field<sup>dei</sup>.
Isokrates put a speech in his mouth that he was supposed to have delivered at the Peace Congress in Sparta in 366/5<sup>p</sup>.
In 362 he was occupied in the defense of Sparta against the Thebans<sup>fj</sup>.
After the death of Agesilaos II in the winter of 360/59 he ascended the throne<sup>k</sup>.

At the outbreak of the Sacred War Archidamos in secret helped the Phocians<sup>mq</sup>. Around 352 he fought against Megalopolis<sup>r</sup>, and in 346 led an army to help Phocis, but because of the ambiguities of the situation among the Phocian leaders returned to Sparta with nothing accomplished<sup>sv</sup>.

After that he was sent to Italy to help Tarentum in a war against the Lucanians. He sailed first to Crete where he refounded Lyttos. In Italy he fought a battle at Mandonion 338—on the seventh of the month Metageitnion<sup>l</sup>—lost the battle and his life<sup>gmtuv</sup>.
He had a portrait bust in Olympia<sup>n</sup> and a statue in Delphi<sup>w</sup>.

descriptions.description: In 431 he saved Methone from an Athenian attack<sup>a</sup>. He was the eponymous ephor of the year 431/30, though he was quite young (but still met the age qualification)<sup>tv</sup>.

In the next year under the command of Knemos he took part in the sea battle at Rhion and Naupaktos and in the attack on Salamis<sup>b</sup>. In the same duty he took part in 427 in the expedition against Corcyra of Alkidas<sup>cd</sup>. In the battle at Pylos he distinguished himself and was badly wounded<sup>eu</sup>.

In the next year he gathered his forces in Corinth and Sicyon for the Thracian expedition and in Autumn 424 reached Thessaly. After a short march against the Lyncestan king Arrhabaios he turned himself to Chalcidice and brought over the wavering cities to his side. He fought from time to time with various fortune against Arrhadaios and the cities Potidaea and Torone, and in the second half of October 422 triumphed finally over Kleon in the decisive batttle at Amphipolis, but in it he, himself, was fatally wounded<sup>fghijkln</sup>. The citizens of Amphipolis buried him in the city and honored him as hero and founder<sup>lm</sup>.

In Sparta a cenotaph was erected for him<sup>r</sup>. Brasidas and the Acanthians had a common treasury in Delphi<sup>p</sup>. Direct descendants of his are known from Augustan times<sup>q</sup>. The heroism of Brasidas remained proverbial for a long time<sup>s</sup>.
